page.title: 06INDUSTRY.
page.content: The cap of Titterstone Clee Hill is formed from a hard igneous rock known as Dhu Stone,which was very popular for road-making and used all over the country for sett-making.Dhu Stone is still quarried on the west side of Titterstone and from 1908 Dhu Stone was quarried on the east side near the Magpie at Catherton. There was no easy way to carry this stone away and so an aerial rope-way was constructed to carry buckets of stone on wire-ropes supported by trestles from Catherton via an angle-station to Detton Ford,where it was transferred to railway trucks and taken on the Ditton Priors railway to Cleobury Mortimer where it was transferred to the main ralway lines and was taken all over the country to be used for roads.
